segments.text: After going to the pool in New York City, I was transferred to Baltimore to work there out of the headquarters of the Third Service Command.
There, of course, the veterinarians went into the packing houses and inspected all of the meat products and anything that the packing houses produced that they sold to the Army had to be inspected.
not only for quality, but for quantity control.
If they hadn't had someone there controlling the quality of the products, we would be paying, the taxpayers would be paying for water and fat in the canned meats, and the frankfurters and bologna.
Everything had to be sampled at random.
to be sure that we didn't get too much fat, too much water in the products, as well as for quantity and quality control.
That, of course, was the thing that we did in many assignments.
I, of course, was able to attend a school in Chicago.
They called it the Quartermaster Depot
where we were assigned, and we went to school there two months and learned how to do these inspections.
Also, of course, I was assigned, the nicest assignment that I received was going down to Fort Myer, Virginia, where we had a hospital for animals.
We treated the horses that are used there for pulling the caissons that were
used when the presidents and other dignitaries had their funerals.
And these caissons, of course, were pulling the coffins to the Arlington Cemetery.
Arlington National Cemetery?
Right.
Arlington National Cemetery was adjacent to Fort Myer, Virginia.
And that's the reason the clinic was there at Fort Myer.
And I also, one morning, got to meet Mrs. Eisenhower because she and the General Eisenhower were stationed there.
She brought her little Scottish terriers out, and we boarded them and treated them with vaccinations.
It was a post where General Hap Arnold, General Marshall,
and several other generals were there over the period of time that I was there.
And I lived in the bachelor officer's quarters, had to wear a number one uniform, and we never knew who would be in the same
room with us.
So we had to be prepared to salute a general just any day while we were stationed at Fort Myer.
It was the most interesting assignment that I had.

Well, while you were in the armed services, as the war was drawing to a close in the mid to latter part of the 40s, what were you thinking about for the future now that you were a doctor of veterinary medicine?
Did you want to come back to Texas?
What did you have in mind then?
After I left Fort Myer, Virginia, I was sent to New York City in a pool.
And of course, while I was there, I again had to do some inspection of food in the packing house.
But I wrote to Henderson, Texas, to see if they needed a veterinarian.
I was looking at the map of East Texas, and I saw the beautiful traffic circle.
And I thought, well, that highway at least has a good highway system.
I wrote the Chamber of Commerce and asked them if they needed a veterinarian.
And they wrote me and replied that yes, they needed a young veterinarian.
They had one older man who was semi-retired, Dr. Ken Deason.
So I knew before I left New York, I was interested in Henderson.
But I had only been at home in Gilmer about three days when I received an emergency call to go to Mount Pleasant in Titus County and help vaccinate all the cattle in the county against anthrax.
It had become an epidemic.
So I went up there and I helped Dr. Norman Ralston for one month.
I was home only three or four days and I got a call from Shreveport.
So Dr. Young in Shreveport, A.V.
Young out at Dixie Garden,
clinic needed a young veterinarian.
So I decided, well, it's a good chance to get an internship.
After being in the army for three years, I needed an internship.
So I went to Shreveport, started working for $175 a month.
as a young veterinarian.
When was this, in about 46 or 45?
That was in 46.
So after staying there about 10 or 11 months, Dr. Young says, well, if you stay over here, you're going to have to take the Louisiana State Board.
So I told him, well, since I plan to live in East Texas the rest of most of my life, I'll just move to Henderson.
So I wrote to Chamber of Commerce or called them,
And they said, oh, yes, we still need a veterinarian.
So I came and visited the Chamber of Commerce, lived in the old Randolph Hotel for two or three days.
And the chamber manager carried me out to Mr. Gordon Brown's store and introduced me to Gordon Brown.
And I rented the two rooms on the north side of his filling station and grocery store and stayed in that neighborhood for several years.
And after I could practice there, and of course we were only charging about $2 for a rabies vaccine and $3 or $4 for the other distemper, hepatitis vaccine.
We treated, mainly we treated cattle.
90% of the practice was cattle.
People couldn't afford to treat their pets, evidently.
And they didn't know very much about
having services available for pets.
They did the best they could with home remedies.
So most of your practice was on cattle at that time?
Cattle.
I would say 85 to 90 percent cattle.
We had cattle all over the city.
What types of cattle?
40 or 50 milk cows.
Okay.
Out in the oil field, cattle were running open range through the oil field in many places.
but many of those people who were working for the oil companies had milk cows, and we had dairies at that time, 30 to 30, maybe 36 at least.
I believe Mr. Felix Burton told me there were 36 dairies here in the late 40s.
I remember five or six in Brockville.
We made a living treating cattle, and it was a hard way to make a living.
But our expenses weren't great.
Mr. Gordon Brown only charged me a small 27 and a half was my overhead for rent, and he answered my telephone.
And of course, we could get by.
We did very little pet work.
When we started spaying dogs, we only charged $10.
You could get dogs spayed for $10, most anywhere.
I had one man who was a truck driver, brought two dogs in.
He said, what will you charge me if I have two spade at one time?
And I said, about $9 each.
He says, well, I can take them to a veterinarian over near Buckner's Orphanage Home in Dallas, get them done for $7.
So that, you see, was a different fee schedule from what veterinarians were able to charge the last few years.
Yeah, sounds like it.
Well, where did you, where were your offices located?
You said you were in Gordon Brown's store, off of his store in a little room.
Where did you move around during the years?
Well, I stayed there until I built my new clinic out near the traffic circle, the one that Dr. Rumbo now owns.
Right.
What year was that?
I think it was 1959.
Okay.
Well, how did your practice grow over the years?
When did you start treating, you know, pets and things like that?
Well, the practice gradually grew.
And, of course, after building the clinic, I could see that I couldn't do justice to both small animals and large animals without having some help.
So I hired Dr.
Norman Ralston, of course, came and practiced with me for a while.
And also Dr. Lovick worked with me for a while.
And Dr. Rumbo was hired in 1970.
And then later we hired Dr. Corley.
There were three of us there for a while.
And, of course, we also had work to do with testing all the cattle.

in russ county for brucellosis that was the bangs disease program when every cow in the county had to be tested and jack rayford used to bring his truck out every morning and he and i would go out and test two or three herds of cattle in the time that all the cows had to be tested we'd schedule two or three herds a day but at that time i still had to come back and get caught up at the clinic
Well, our guest this morning, let me take a break right here and tell you, is Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, doctor of veterinary medicine who's retired here of Henderson and Russ County.
He practiced veterinary medicine here in Henderson for 38 years.
His practice started, I believe, in September of 1947.
He retired in 1985.
And of course, if you've been in
Henderson et al.
Before those years, you've heard of Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, doctor of veterinary medicine.
We're talking about the history of veterinary medicine in Texas, and now we're down to the specifics of his career and also what's going to be going on here in Russ County.
Let's see, were you a single man when you moved here in 1947?
You might better bring us up to date on the important stuff here.
Yeah, I was very single.
Okay.
I met my wife here in 1947 at church, and of course I was able to have a little time, you know, to devote to courting, but not much.
So it took me a while to decide that perhaps I might be old enough to get married.
So finally we became engaged.
And married in 49.
1949, right.
And had two daughters, of course, Melanie Taylor and Sarah Ann Cobb are our two daughters.
Let's don't forget the grandkids now.
And, of course, we have three grandchildren, Blake Taylor and Adam Taylor.
and Miss Stephanie Carr down in Bryan, Texas.
Okay.
We definitely had to get those ladies and the grandkids in this.
It wouldn't be an interview if we didn't.
But what I want to get to now is some of the more interesting cases you've seen here in Russ County.
Now, you worked with...
A lot of people in Russell County, as you said, you were a people person.
You worked with the farmers and the ranchers and the county agents.
You've worked with several county agents over the years, including Mr. Felix Burton, you've named earlier.
Let's just go back and kind of reminisce about some of these different diseases you've seen, maybe some unusual things and problems that you faced and how you overcame them.
Well, one of the most unusual things that
we were seeing in cattle when I first came here in 47 was being called X disease because we didn't know what else to call it.
The first case that I saw was north of Laneville on a farm of Jack Mosley in 1947, my first year in practice in Russ County.
Later it was seen in caves at the John R. Alford Dairy out on the Overton Highway.
when approximately 12 or 15 of his calves were sick and dying with this strange disease.
It was also diagnosed on a farm owned by Major Hall, east of Henderson.
This disease was not described in the textbook and had never been seen before by veterinarians or cattlemen.
Symptoms seen in this condition were the loss of hair and wrinkling of the skin on their necks,
in the thoracic area of their chest.
Tearing was very profuse, with the tears dripping from their chins of the calves.
Ulcers were present in the mouth and the stomach, along with severe diarrhea in some cases.
At that time, I consulted A&M College, and Dr. Hubert Smith was sent to help with the observation and diagnosis of these strange diseases.

Soon after Dr. Smith spent the day here visiting these herds of sick animals, he wrote me that the condition had been diagnosed as hyperkeratitis due to cattle licking axle grease and other farm lubricants.
It was also seen where newly treated creosoted timbers were being used in barnyards.
The offending chemical was chlorinated hydrocarbons used as preservatives in farm lubricants.
Once the cause was known, the government outlawed the use of these preservatives and the disease disappeared.
Before they learned what it was, at least a half a million cattle were lost.
in the southern states.

My goodness, just from licking these farm lubricants off of... And it was also getting into the cubes, the cattle feed, going through the machinery, the cube that the cattle were fed had contained some of that chemical.
Another very unusual condition that we saw down on the farm of Edgar Lee Keeling.
Mr. Keeling lived east of Brockville there on Clayton Highway.
He was feeding some sweet potatoes to two herds of cattle in two different pastures because the potatoes had rotten spots on them.
After the third or fourth feeding of the sweet potatoes, the cattle began to get sick because they couldn't breathe.
They had this condition which, of course, was due
to the fungus growing on the potato called pulmonary adenomatosis, a rare disease that can happen if the potatoes are beginning to rot.
This was only seen once in Russ County, but he lost approximately 60 head of cattle that he fed these potatoes.
There was another real unusual thing that took place.
White muscle disease was the diagnosis.
One year during the mid-50s, a Russ County area had an early freeze causing many acorns to fall from the trees at one time.
At this time, several dozen cattlemen found from two to six cows down and unable to walk.
These downer cows were all passing coffee-colored urine and lived only three or four days.
They all died regardless of what you treated them with.
Approximately 12 East Texas veterinarians met in Nacogdoches and came to the conclusion that these cattle were probably suffering from the tannic acid poison due to the acorns.
One or two weeks later, after our meeting in Nacogdoches, this condition was diagnosed by an A&M veterinarian as white muscle disease due to the deficiency of vitamin E

during the dry period of summer and fall I have recently learned however that this unusual condition seen only one year was more likely caused by the cattle eating the poison weed that is commonly referred to as coffee beans which is very toxic after the early freeze in the fall also a very interesting thing that happened to us was that cattle were dying
Suddenly, in the Harmony Hill community south of Tatum, several family milk cows died in one neighborhood.
This alarmed Commissioner R.E.
Doc Young, who consulted me.
The specimens taken from the dead animal that we did the postmortem on were sent to diagnostic laboratories at A&M in Austin.
The diagnosis confirmed that the
cattle were dying with anthrax.

The County Agent Felix Burton, the Commissioner's Court, and Dr. Richard Winters, a veterinarian with the State Health Department, convened, and we decided to quietly vaccinate all adjacent premises against the disease.
The news of this epidemic was not released to the media in order to keep the cattle traders from unofficially boycotting Russ County cattle.
A few years later, one cow died suddenly at the Dulaney Ranch between Henderson and Laneville.
This animal had classical post-mortem symptoms of anthrax.
I noticed the cow was bleeding from all of her external openings.
Therefore, I suspected anthrax.
I sent specimens to the laboratory, and they confirmed that this cow
died with anthrax.
We still don't know where the disease came from because we hadn't ever had any anthrax in that part of the county.
But it was confirmed to be anthrax.
We again met with Mr. Burton and commissioners court and the state veterinarian and decided to do the same thing.
We vaccinated all the adjacent premises and stopped that epidemic before it got into the newspaper and the radio and the life magazine.
They had it in the life magazine when they had an outbreak in Southern Oklahoma a few years earlier and almost ruined the cattle industry in that area.
But all the anthrax epidemics that did occur were taken care of quickly and isolated in different parts of the county.

In this county, we've only had cattle die in two different places, and we only lost about eight or ten cattle in the first epidemic before vaccination started, and I only lost one cow on the Dulaney Ranch.
Okay.
Okay.
I have some other interesting things if you have time.
Sure.
Let's go ahead.
We're making history here today.
We've got you here at the radio station.
By the way, our guest is Dr. Hugh M. Phillips, retired doctor of veterinary medicine.
He practiced 38 years here in Russ County in Henderson.

and of course retired in 1985, and he and his other cohorts, Texas A&M and veterinarians, are compiling a book that's going to be coming out called The History of Veterinary Medicine in Texas, and we've covered a lot of the history this morning, and we're down to the specifics in Russ County and what you've seen as a vet here in Henderson.
What are some of the other things that you've seen?
Well, some of the most perplexing things that I saw
was lead poisoning and arsenic poisoning in cattle.
Before the Russ County farmers quit raising cotton, arsenic was used to poison insects on the cotton.
The leftover arsenic was not always easy to, easy or safely stored or destroyed.
People still don't know what to do with several pounds of arsenic.
One rancher, Ray Calvert, who had moved here and
had the Santa Gertrudis trading business.
He sent cattle all over the world.
I remember doing some work for Ray Cowart and sending some cattle to Vietnam before the war with Vietnam.
He had leased a pasture from Otis Wiley down at Laneville.
He had 50 head of valuable Santa Gertrudis cattle.
One week, these cattle broke into the barn
And they found, just by milling around in that barn, they found arsenic that had been stored there in a five gallon milk can.
And the bottom had rusted out of this can.
The cattle knocked the can over and there must have been 30 or 40 pounds of arsenic in the can.
All of those cattle had licked on that arsenic for two or three days because it was salty tasting.
They all started dying.

We called A&M College to see if there was any treatment they would recommend that was new, and I was told that there was nothing you could do if they had eaten arsenic and you hadn't started your treatment the first day.
So he lost at least 50 head of valuable Santa Catruta's cattle from the arsenic that they consumed.
Ralph Ballinger, who lived
just north of Henderson, lost several large hogs when they rooted up a can of arsenic that had been buried in the barnyard by his father.
The hogs, of course, normally get out and start rooting around in the soil, and they found that arsenic.
And he, of course, lost all of his big fat hogs that he planned to kill.
Cattlemen in the Gaston and Joinerville area lost cattle one year when one oil well servicing company used a treater solution in cleaning some of the old oil wells.
Arsenic was suspected.
Some of this oil around the wells was tested and found to contain arsenic.
These few cattle were lost, but after the company learned about the cattle dying, they paid for the cattle and no more losses occurred.
Lead poisoning cattle was seen
on several occasions when young cattle would lick or drink water from lead paint buckets that were left around barnyards by careless owners.
Most people have now learned to be more careful with their paint buckets.
Also, a very interesting epidemic was seen in 1951 to 1953 when Russ County and other adjacent counties suffered a rabies epidemic in foxes, dogs, and cattle.
Foxes were chasing cattlemen up trees when they would go to feed their cattle.
Rabies in cattle and dogs was hard to diagnose clinically.
Some had only the dumb rabies symptoms with paralysis of the lower jaw, while others would be violent and vicious.
Many cattle owners were exposed and had to be treated with the
Pasteur treatment, it's called.
We're talking about rabies now.
Right.
Was there a specific time period that this was a big problem?
It was in the early 50s in this county.
You said foxes and dogs and cattle now.
I don't see too many foxes now.
I know that there are, but there used to be a lot more, I guess.
In the early 50s, we had a lot of foxes and we had a lot of fox hunters.
Now we don't have either.
And the reason is because the state health department was called in to talk to the cattlemen and the dog owners.
We met in the district courtroom and authorities decided to warn the dog owners to confine their dogs while strychnine was used to poison the foxes, the coyotes, and stray dogs.
This procedure was very unpopular with the fox hunters, but the rabies epidemic was brought under control shortly
after the program was finished.
The fox population in Russ County never has replenished.
Right.
Okay, now we hear of skunks nowadays.
They're fairly plentiful, not as many as you see in other parts of Texas, but they're one of the animals that spread rabies too.
What other animals are carriers here in the East Texas area?
Any warm-blooded animal.
can have rabies.

Before I moved to Henderson, a man out in the Churchill area named Poole, I don't think he was closely related to the other Poole family in this county, but he had killed a squirrel, and some of his family remembered that this squirrel bit him, and he died with rabies.
And of course, any warm-blooded animal, we have seen a lot of rabid skunks in the county, but
For some reason, even though we find rabid skunks often, we've been lucky and haven't had too many rabid animals.
We've had a few rabid cats and a few rabid dogs.
But with the vaccination procedure that most people are doing on their pets, rabies has been brought under control.
And there's two types of rabies, aren't there?
Yes.
Can you explain the two and the different symptoms?
That's what makes it so confusing.
The first time I saw a rabid animal was when I was about 8 or 10 years old.
And I had a, well, my family had a bird dog, pointer.
Everybody in east part of Gilmer knew about old Rap because he was such a fine bird dog.
He came home one day with the paralysis of his lower jaw and his tongue hanging out of his mouth.
And I consulted my neighbor, my father, and they consulted the pharmacist who was helping people make diagnosis.
And most all of the people that saw the dog thought he had sore mouth, which was a common disease among dogs.
